raw_text:
Brit awards for Devon music acts
 
 Devon singer Joss Stone and rock band Muse won coveted Brit awards during the event's 25th anniversary.
 
 Seventeen-year-old Stone, from near Cullumpton, won two awards: best British female act, and best urban act out of three award nominations. Muse, whose members met in south Devon, beat Franz Ferdinand, Jamie Cullum, Kasabian and The Libertines for best British live act. The band has sold about two million records worldwide.
 
 After beating Amy Winehouse, Jamelia, Natasha Bedingfield and PJ Harvey to the best British female prize, Joss Stone said: "I don't know what to say. I don't like doing this at all. I'd like to thank my family for being really supportive and everybody that made my record with me." "I don't even know what to do right now. Thank you all you guys for voting for me, I feel sick right now." Viewers of digital music TV channel MTV Base voted Stone the winner in the best urban act category. Ms Stone also performed her song Right To Be Wrong, backed by a gospel choir, at the 25th award ceremony at London's Earls Court. Her second album Mind, Body & Soul reached number one in the UK charts last October and went straight into the US charts at number 11.
 
 The teenager also has Grammy nominations in the US, normally dominated by home-grown acts. Born Jocelyn Stoker, the Devon diva started her career in a BBC talent programme, and was then discovered at a New York audition by a US record executive, Steve Greenberg. Indie Rock group Muse consists of Matthew Bellamy, Chris Wolstenholme and Dominic Howard who met in their early teens in Teignmouth, south Devon. Dominic Howard said of winning: "We love playing live, it's very important for our band. So to win something like this really feels great." The trio met aged 13 and formed the band Gothic Plague, changing its name to Fixed Penalty, Rocket Baby Dolls and finally Muse. The band released its first self-titled EP in 1998. The third studio album, Absolution, was released in 2003, providing the hit singles Time Is Running Out, Hysteria, and Butterflies And Hurricanes.

Joss Stone won two Brit awards: best British female act and best urban act. She performed at the ceremony alongside her band Muse, who beat Franz Ferdinand for best live act. 

Muse has sold over 2 million records worldwide. They were nominated for the award with their song Right To Be Wrong backed by a gospel choir.

Joss Stone thanked her family for support and praised viewers who voted for her on MTV Base. Muse has sold 2 million records worldwide and credited their live performances as important to their success.

Muse's self-titled EP was released in 1998 followed by their third studio album *Absolution* which included hits like "Time Is Running Out", "Hysteria," and "Butterflies And Hurricanes."

Devon singer Joss Stone won Best British Female Act and Best Urban Act at the event, showcasing her talent as a teenager. Muse, a rock band from south Devon, also secured Best British Live Act with them beating Franz Ferdinand, Jamie Cullum, and Kasabian. Their album sold over two million records globally. Stones live performance on MTV Base was well-received, and she received a Grammy nomination in the US. Jocelyn Stoker, Joss Stone's daughter, began her career through BBC talent shows and later discovered Muse during an audition by Steve Greenberg. Muse's journey includes forming Gothic Plague before renaming to Fixed Penalty Rocket Baby Dolls and achieving success with their EP in 1998 and subsequent hits in 2003.

granite3.1-dense:2b:
During the 25th anniversary of Brit Awards, Devon music acts Joss Stone and Muse secured prestigious accolades. Joss Stone, a 17-year-old singer from Cullumpton, claimed two awards: best British female act and best urban act (voted for by MTV Base viewers). Her second album, Mind, Body & Soul, topped the UK charts in October and reached number 11 in the US. Stone expressed gratitude to her family and supporters after defeating other contenders like Amy Winehouse, Jamelia, Natasha Bedingfield, PJ Harvey, Franz Ferdinand, Jamie Cullum, Kasabian, and The Libertines for best British live act.

Muse, an indie rock band hailing from Teignmouth, south Devon, won best British live act. Formed in their teens as Gothic Plague and later known as Fixed Penalty, Rocket Baby Dolls, and Muse, the group has sold approximately two million records worldwide. Guitarist Dominic Howard highlighted the significance of live performances for Muse, emphasizing their delight at winning this award. The band released its first EP in 1998 and gained prominence with their third studio album, Absolution (2003), featuring hit singles like Time Is Running Out, Hysteria, and Butterflies And Hurricanes.
reference: Devon singer Joss Stone and rock band Muse won coveted Brit awards during the event's 25th anniversary.Seventeen-year-old Stone, from near Cullumpton, won two awards: best British female act, and best urban act out of three award nominations.Muse, whose members met in south Devon, beat Franz Ferdinand, Jamie Cullum, Kasabian and The Libertines for best British live act.After beating Amy Winehouse, Jamelia, Natasha Bedingfield and PJ Harvey to the best British female prize, Joss Stone said: "I don't know what to say.I don't like doing this at all.The band has sold about two million records worldwide."I don't even know what to do right now.I'd like to thank my family for being really supportive and everybody that made my record with me."
